en: Vida y hechos del ingenioso cavallero Don Quixote de la Mancha

In the center, don Quixote, mounted on Rocinante and wearing the barber basin, and Sancho Panza, embracing the head of his donkey.At each side, on pedestals, "AMADIS" and "ROLANDO"; both as Roman soldiers.Above, a medallion with Dulcinea's portrait.Good drawing and engraving.
1 - Copied after Savery's frontispiece for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
Don Quixote fighting against the Basque and windmills
8.2 Adventure of the windmills (giants)8.3 Episode with friars of St. Benedict8.4 Adventure with the Basque

Three different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the background, the first one: don Quixote attacks the windmills while Sancho tries to stop him.In the middle ground, the second one: Sancho is beaten by the Benedictine monks' servants.In the foreground, don Quixote fights with the Basque, while a Basque lady observes them from her carriage.The Basque holding a stool is not accurate to Cervantes' text; it should be a cushion.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
14.1 Episode of Grisóstomo and Marcela, continuation14.2 Grisóstomo´s song14.3 Marcela’s appearance and speech14.4 Burial of Grisóstomo

The background is divided in two parts: underneath, the dead shepherd Grisóstomo, his friend Ambrosio, Vivaldo reading Grisóstomo's song and don Quixote; above, Marcela's appearance and speech.Marcela's figure copies saint Gabriel's traditional image.In the foreground, several shepherds digging Grisóstomo's grave.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.

In the foreground, don Quixote lying over the broken bed; meanwhile, in the background, the fight between Sancho, Maritornes and the muleteer is discovered by the innkeeper, who holds a candle.Poor drawing and engraving.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
Sancho Panza's blanketing and don Quixote fighting with the flock of sheep

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the foreground, Sancho's blanketing is observed by don Quixote from behind the inn wall.In the background, don Quixote fighting with a flock of sheep.Simple composition that will be used until the 20th century.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
Cardenio attacks don Quixote and Sancho Panza
24.1 Story of Cardenio24.3 Cardenio attacks DQ and SP

In the foreground, Cardenio fighting against don Quixote, fallen defeated, and Sancho, protecting his head; the goatherd arrives to help them.Simple composition.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable, but simple and without many details.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
Dispute at the inn about Mambrino's helmet (barber basin) and packsaddle
45.1 Dispute at inn about the Mambrino’s helmet and packsaddle (albarda)

In the center of the composition, don Quixote with Mambrino's helmet (barber basin) shouting to calm down the fighting around him (Agramante's Camp); also don Fernando, officers of justice, innkeeper...On the left, Sancho and the barber fighting for the packsaddle.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.

1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.3 - The illustration has been placed according to its own reference, "Fol. 331", in chapter 30:1 (Libro IV, Parte I, Cap. XXX), but it belongs to chapter 45:1 (Libro IV, Parte I, Cap. XLV), where it appears the illus. "DQ punishing SP" f.p. 536.
Dorotea knelt down before don Fernando
36.2 Resolution of love affairs of Cardenio and Luscinda, Dorotea and Don Fernando

Dorotea recognises don Fernando and Luscinda, who has lost her mask (tafetán), and, knelt down before don Fernando, begs him to let Luscinda go with Cardenio; Sancho, the priest and the barber observe them.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.

Dorotea (Micomicona) prevents don Quixote from punishing Sancho for having preferred Micomicona's beauty to Dulcinea's.Also the priest, Cardenio and the barber, disguised as Micomicona's page with a fake beard.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.

1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.3 - The illustration has been placed according to its own reference, "Fol. 537", in chapter 45:1 (Libro IV, Parte I, Cap. XLV), but it belongs to chapter 30:1 (Libro IV, Parte I, Cap. XXX), where it appears the illus. "Dispute at the inn" f.p. 331.
DON QUIXOTE CAVALLERO DE LOS LEONES.

Frontispiece based on don Quixote's Part II iconography (17:2).Don Quixote, as Knight of the Lions (one lion appears beside him), holds a sword and a sun faced shield.Behind him, over a semicircle wall, Dulcinea, enchanted as an old peasant woman, and Sancho, as governor.Between them, a medallion with Merlin's portrait.Acceptable drawing and engraving.
1 - Copied after Savery's frontispiece for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter a cart with players
11.1 Adventure of the cart of actors; “cortes de la muerte”

Thebojigangasteals Sancho's donkey while the squire goes to don Quixote's assistance (falling with Rocinante in the background).In the cart, the actors of Angulo el Malo's company for theCortes de la Muerte(Devil, Cupid, Death, Angel, Emperor, Queen and Soldier); there is one additional player not from Cervantes' text.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.

In the foreground, don Quixote is prepared to fight with a lion while the lionkeeper opens the gate of the cage.In the background, Sancho and don Diego de Miranda running away.This composition, with not many changes, will be used until the 20th century.Drawing and engraving are poor.
1 - Copied after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657.2 - The same plate will be used for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 and later editions.
